comments.commentBody:
Step one was delegitimizing traditional media by calling it mainstream media and claiming that it was all politically biased against the right.

Step two was claiming that traditional media is nothing but a pack of lies.

Step three is proclaiming that we are now officially in post truth America where convincing the listener is all that matters.

Step four was using all three above to get an incompetent demagogue elected to the Presidency.

Step four was for the demagogue to appoint an extremist fanatic as his chief law enforcement officer (AG) solely because of his unyielding support.

Step five is for the new AG to circumvent the laws he is will soon be sworn to uphold in order to secure his appointment.

Step five is for the new AG to do whatever the demagogue wants in order to further his political agenda which is primarily concerned with installing a permanent oligarchy to rule America.

Step six is selling out America to big money and ultra-nationalists, all in the name of God, glory and the flag.

Step seven is the end of liberty, the establishment of tyranny and the debasement of our cherished political system, which we used to call democracy.

That my friends is a seven step program designed to turn America into an monied aristocracy instead of a nation of laws.

None of this happened by accident. Jeff Sessions is now a key player in the scam.

Enjoy our new rulers. Governing is so old school. Being ruled is much more efficient. No need for those pesky laws.
Enough about the the Obama presidency though. It's old news.

Just to make sure I understand you: all of the above is fine with you as long as we deport "illegal immigrant labor," right? All those meat processing jobs, strawberry and tomato picking, etc., we should make sure they go to native-born Americans, is that it?
This was in reply to Roger Wilson Corman, Jr.
So much for the Times article that Packers fans remember the playoff losses more than the victories.  I guess the Packers were too busy preparing for the Giants to have time to read it.

I hope people will check in with our former governor, Deval Patrick, who effectively defended voting rights against a barrage of dodgy attacks and assertions. Breitbart, as always, has turned this backwards.

"For 30 years I have viewed the prosecution of the Perry County Three as a cautionary tale. I believe it demonstrates what can happen when prosecutorial discretion is unchecked, when regard for facts is secondary to political objectives. What can happen is that the rule of law is imperiled. In a republic based on law, this is not the kind of risk any of us should accept in an attorney general."

http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2017/01/sessions-chose-the-wrong-si...

And then there are his attacks on climate scientists. He thinks they are ungodly, but it is he who ignores the gospels and the teachings of Jesus, to care for each other and our world.

I believe Deval Patrick wrote a letter to the Denate recommending against confirmation based on his early role in defending two African Americans in a specious and silly case presided ove by none other than Mr. trump's nominee for Justice.

Deficit spending requires the government to sell bonds which competes with other kinds of investment like corporate bonds and mortgages and crowds out investment. The additional government spending creates jobs, but the reduction in private spending because they can't borrow as much money reduces jobs cancelling it out. "Crowding in" is a much less common term, but it refers to when government spending when we are in a liquidity trap has the the opposite effect and actually increases private spending and private job creation rather than reducing it.

I believe Deval Patrick wrote a letter to the Denate recommending against confirmation based on his early role in defending two African Americans in a specious and silly case presided ove by none other than Mr. trump's nominee for Justice.

The New York Times needs to take a page from more serious reporting. Occasionally they do real reporting, but day after day we can reliably count on opinionating rather than informing. For example, we are looking at history-making floods in California, but where is that news? All over the globe, extreme weather is providing daily evidence of change. This accumulating information is something everyone needs to know. Denial of climate science and global warming/climate change would not be so easy if reporting followed its duty to tell the story.

In the end, the planet is more powerful than the mountebank and his kleptocracy, and their eagerness to shut down science and silence their critics. Being "fair" to this does not serve us well.

This guy doesn't need to be "figured out", it's all too obvious what he's up to. The New York Times should not play patsy to this.

"Mr. Trump has great gifts in the art of vengeance and humiliation. It is a ribald form of wit that can make voters laugh with the scornful jeer that, for a moment, irons out the inequalities between the 1 percent and the rest of the nation. Andrew Breitbart had it; Sarah Palin almost did. Mr. Trump has it in spades."

Dear Susan Anderson: if you were to give a functioning link (regarding the Bloomberg article ), I would like to read the story that you have provided as a reference… Thanks, but the link don't work on my compfuser, I'm sorry.

Susan, I agree that "day after day we rely on opinionating rather than informing," in the format promoted by Dean Baquet since he is at the helm.  Sadly, the opinions are always (99.9%) the same, thus both predictable and repetitive, which makes for a dreadfully boring read.
@nasty man.....just select the link with your mouse and paste it into your browser search box----i got it presto.

Here's an example of great reporting. All too often this is not coming from the NYT, but from others:

https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2017-01-04/house-gop-gives-s...

"House GOP Gives Staff Broader New Powers to Grill Witnesses"

"A little-noticed provision approved Tuesday by the U.S. House dramatically expands the powers of committee staff to haul private citizens and government officials to Capitol Hill to be questioned under oath -- without any lawmakers present, in some cases.

"The Republican-authored change included in a House rules package marks what Democrats says is a disturbing trend of giving staff powers that have traditionally been reserved for members of Congress."

Other than one managed portfolio account, and one bond fund, I have my own fund. I do not pay fees, I do pay capital gains taxes, and $8.59 a trade, and that is it. along with that I have a no charge bank account with the broker, and a line of credit at 3.5% that I used for a kitchen remodel.

When I went to Spain last fall, I took a debit card on my brokerage bank account, it has no exchange fees like most credit cards do. So I saved a few percent on purchases, and did not have a credit card bill to pay when we got back.

I do not need to pay someone to buy what I can buy on my own and only pay once, and it is held in my name. For instance when I look at the 10K for Con Ed, I see at least three funds holding it. Same for Merck, and other well paying equities.

Funds will be the destruction of the market with their buying out companies and taking them private. The fund manager are the highest paid of all the investors, and they get paid even if you lose.
Just don't let Pete Rose in...
Jenkins and Beckham are a couple of clowns.
No mention of the helmet first illegal hit causing #1 receiver to leave the game?  Of course no penalty was called so it must not have been illegal--right?

Eric, I,too, was astonished by the lack of a penalty on that cheap shot. It was also a very illegal "spearing" penalty.  Two things should have happened on the spot: first, the 15 yard penalty for "unnecessary roughness." and two, an automatic ejection of the player who committed such a penalty. I know this is a tough and rough game. But there are rules, and you and I seem to know them better than the officials. I would have demanded a review before going to the next play. Go figure ...
@David O.: Not reviewable--yet. They just assess fines after the game's over, unfortunately. I suspect some penalty/lack of penalty calls will become reviewable in the coming years, though.

EXACTLY Eric!  Did the referees not see Jordy Nelson get hit in the ribs by Giants defensive back Leon Hall's helmet or simply not care?  One would expect a higher level of professionalism and work product from the referees when it comes to the playoffs.  The last time I checked , this was the MAJOR leagues, not Pop Warner stuff.  Good grief.
So, who's gonna pay for the wall (repairs)?
Mexico?
The Mexicans, duh.
I think they should leave it un-repaired, as a kind of testament to the powers of not giving up and teamwork.

Ignorance isn't incurable, and there is always the hope that one day all newspapers, radio, and television newspeople will explain policy to the American people as if they were intelligent. This is quite likely to happen about the time when Trump's foolish policies result in consequences that voters hate. There is nothing like being proven to have made a terrible decision to motivate a person to learn how to make better ones.

A healthy democracy requires an well-informed electorate equiped to understand the relevant information. We will either convince American voters that having the facilities to lie easily, to hurl purile insults based on irrelevancies, to avoid civilized discussion, are not the qualities that make for a successful leader. Our choices are only between educating voters or excluding them from the process of choosing their leaders, in other words giving up on democracy. The first choice is the better one, and Paul Krugman is the best popular educator on topics that voters need to understand. Not all good medicine is fun to take.
extra puzzler -- sports bra changed to sports bar. Good Monday. Goatherd reminds me of The Sound of Music. Julie Andrews was just host of the New Year's celebration with the Vienna Philharmonic.

“Of all the gin joints in all the towns in all the world, [he] walks into mine.”

Sen. Jeff Sessions is a hard-case for law enforcement: former federal prosecutor in Bama (successful one), he NEVER votes to empty our prisons. Now, this worldview is appropriate in the U.S. Senate, where ALL the many worldviews of Americans are represented. But as our AG, running the U.S. dept. charged with serving as last bulwark against racism and unfairness in America? Hmmm.

To answer the editorial question, Sen. Sessions is a man hiding in plain sight. He is a recognized champion for a racial balance in America that does his middle name, “Beauregard”, proud. Would he ignore law or make it up in that interest? No, I don’t believe he would. Would he make excuses for what most Americans regard as outrageous racial and ethnic prejudice? Perhaps not pursue it energetically, allowing us to sink back into some retrograde, freckled version of Jim Crow, not so murderous but a hideous return nonetheless to a watered-down version of Hell? I’m … not so sure.

And my lack of sureness is frightening to me.

Trump’s nominees, to me, represent legitimate choices of the political winner: lower taxes, dramatically less suffocating regulation, a decided contempt for political correctness. You don’t like that? Well, elections have consequences, as President Obama was fond of reminding Republicans. All Trump’s nominees but one: Jeff Beauregard Sessions, junior senator from the great state of AL, as our AG.
What is legitimate political choice. There is nothing legitimate about basing our foreign policy towards Russia on the interests of Exxon. That's just corruption.

Trump's nominees, to me and tens of millions of American's, represent illegitimate choices: Trump lost the popular vote by 3 million in a election influenced by fake news and Putin-Assange hackings, and in one handed to him by largely uneducated and duped working class white folks in Red states.

Now we'll have:
- regressive and unfair taxation and even lower taxes for the wealthy
- dramatically more suffocating air and toxic water supplies
- a decided contempt for women, Hispanics and African-Americans
- millions with health insurance, unlike all other advanced societies
- more fossil fuel infrastructure, fracking and earthquakes in Oklahoma
- more military spending, even though we lead by 10-fold the next 8
- counter-proactive and potentially destabilizing trade wars
- complete disregard for the law, transparency and decency
- major threats to our democratic republic

I don't like that. Elections do have consequences. My sureness about the dangers of Trump and his nominees are frightening to me.

Here (from There):

If there is to be confirmation exception, I'd just as soon it was Sessions. The guy is scary. To hell with "counting coup" on Trump -- he's big enough to survive it.

"He is a recognized champion for a racial balance in America that does his middle name, “Beauregard”, proud."

You almost got this one right, Richard. It's his first name that is more relevant in making him proud as a champion of white supremacy. He, like his father before him, was named after Jefferson Davis.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeff_Sessions

Those levels you are so bothered about are the levels that Reagan touted for his 49 state re-election bid in 1984. I don't think it is as bad as you imply.

Funny, when the employment-population ratio was higher during the Clinton administration, the complaint from the right was that there were too many families where both parents were working, and that "family values" were eroding because there were no stay at home moms anymore.

Republicans have a very good "heads we win, tails you lose" game that they employ here. Those of us with decent memories don't fall for it.

NONE of Trump's nominees are "tainted" BUT for Jeff Sessions. They simply espouse different worldviews than you do, gemli. If you'd thought that was a problem, you might have considered moving temporarily to Chicago, voting several thousand times for Mrs. Clinton, then convincing the authorities of several upper-Midwest rustbelt states to extradite all those spurious votes to tip the balance. But it seems that you, like Mrs. Clinton, made altogether too many bad assumptions a couple of months ago, and now will need to abide the consequences. Your berserker support of Bernie Sanders to the bitter end and to the embarrassment of Mrs. Clinton must be particularly galling right about now.

Revolt away. The more recent forebears of Jeff Sessions learned how THAT form of protest is handled here.

You need to cut Sessions some slack as Alabama AG. We must all remember that AL was one of the states, not so long ago, that thought castration of the mentally challenged was appropriate protection against the dangers they represented to the virtue of nice, polite white women. So, defending death sentences for those of them convicted of committing murder can't be TOO hard to understand.

Sessions's record in in AL, as prosecutor and as state AG with regard to BOTH the mentally challenged and most clearly the non-freckled, was (and is) hardly outstanding in the South. But, then, we usually don't regard such pillars as suitable candidates for U.S. attorney general.

As a regular reader of NYT comments and knowing your copious use of sarcasm, I seem to be interpreting this a little differently than some of the others. Unless I am totally off-base, you do not see Sessions as an appropriate pick for AG. Please tell me I'm right.

Miriam:

Now, that's unfair. The Deep South has also depended on the cultivation of peanuts for its prosperity.

Miriam, Cat, Andrew and Soxared:

I DO believe that's what I wrote.

Rima:

How dare you tarnish the great name of Jefferson Davis?

"Jefferson Davis was proud of slavery. He boasted of how the number of slaves in the Southern states had grown from 600,000 to four million in 80 years, and how those 'brute savages' had been turned into 'docile' laborers under the benevolent care of a 'superior race'. Thanks to their work, the South had become civilized and prosperous."

https://www.quora.com/What-were-Jefferson-Davis-views-on-slavery-How-did...

I even included the link. So there.

Dr. K,

The Fed seems to be signaling that they see an increase in price inflation and therefore are telling the world that they are raising interests rates to head inflation off before it shows itself. I don't think this is wise. The Fed would do well to keep interest rates low until we invest in infrastructure, especially the the bad infrastructure that threatens public safety or is a drag on the efficiency of the economy.

You know better than anyone that bridge and tunnel building have high multipliers and can have a very beneficial effect on incomes.

I also strongly believe that we should invest in developing technologies that can capture and sequester carbon dioxide as quickly as possible. Even if we must redirect the missions of our Federal Labs. The private sector is not doing this, so we need to treat this as a national security emergency.

I also believe we should eliminate the barriers to development and deployment of sustainable energy technologies. I don't think people realize the potential for collapse if we persist in avoiding the fossil fuel problem. We are moving much too slowly. The risk is too great.

So I strongly believe we should invest in R&D in electric power generation, Interstate Maglev Logistics transport such as that proposed by the late Senator Moynihan. He had a great idea for complementing our existing Interstate Highways with this 300 mph freight, truck , and passenger surface transport system. See www.magneticglide.com
I was right with you until you got to maglev.

You have to be some kind of nut to pay through the nose to sit in near zero weather for four hours to watch a football game.   What other sport are fans required to endure such conditions to attend a post season game?   Even a northern city World Series game is usually no colder than 40 degrees or so.

Whaaaaa!!!
as a Giants season ticket holder for over 53 years who started to go to the games with his dad when he was 13 years old -you are really clueless about being there in all elements to watch your team live - not on a large screen HDTV on a fuzzy recliner.
If the players can play then as a fan you can cheer and support them.
I remember decades ago when we only had wool clothes to wear -no synthetic fill material and outside shells that are wind and rain proof. plus new boots that keep your feet warm.
We are becoming a nation of wooshies who want to do anything outside in ideal weather. Kids are driven everywhere. We walked or road bikes everywhere.
You miss the whole point of football as a sport.
I am more concerned with the multitude of penalties created and called which stop play so the NFL can make more advertising money. And a TD is called when one centimeter of the tip of the ball "touches" the goal line and then fumbled. It's all becoming a technology farce.
Ya gotta be from Wisconsin to understand... Here's where the ghosts of Curly Lambeau, Nitschke, Lombardi, Magee, et al, roam. This is Title Town! Go Pack Go!

Obviously, you're not from Green Bay nor a Packer share holder. Football's in our blood. It's one of the things that make our beats tick. We grew up in the Vince Lombardi area. We experienced the 1967 Ice Bowl first hand. Packer fans and Cubs fans share a long and rich history of victories and defeats. It's an emotional thing - not a cognitive one.

Dr Krugman,
When I started to question what was negative interest there were those who sought to enlighten me on the technical details.
The very center of Western Civilization has been the value of money.
I understand neoliberalism it has been around for thousands of years.
What does negative interest mean?
The introduction of negative interest questions the very relevance of our economic ideology.
Dr Krugman it is time to leave the safety of your economic temple and enter the world of philosophy. I understand the reluctance to leave the world of economics where you are a superstar and become just another student of philosophy it is here you are needed.
Why are we even talking debt and deficit in a world of negative interest in developed countries.
Neoliberalism has seen the the private sector have so much money we have imposed penalties on having too much. Economics is broken beyond repair and disquietude blamed on the election of a regime that puts all it faith in economic growth is not an alarm over a man who does not understand our economic system but the election of a regime that will never understand that change happens.
There are those of us that state the basis of the modern Western Nation State is interest. Negative interest tells me it is a brand new ballgame. I am not a Christian but the concept of chasing the moneylenders from the temple fills me with optimism. The fact that if we borrow enough we won't need taxes. This isn't wonkdom this is arithmetic.
I am afraid that I am highly dubious about the economic perpetual motion machines.

Robert I call your dubious and raise you an impossibility!
Degrowth September 2017 Budapest.

Looking at Chart 5 from a recent report from the BLS (link given below), we might want to ask the Times to remove Krugman's fake news. He writes.
"Wages are finally rising, quit rates are back to pre-crisis levels, so we seem to be fairly close to full employment, and the Fed is raising rates."

Hardly. No need to argue over interpretation, he's trying to deceive you into thinking we have full employment. This is refuted by actual data. While a majority of 125 million voters agreed with this deception, American economy is great, an all important 50,000 in Wisconsin, Michigan, and Pennsylvania seemed to have a firmer grip on reality. Again, looking at actual data, not only were quit rates pre recession pretty underwhelming (see the other link I'm providing), but the Chart 5 from first link shows the same number of hires and quits ten years later, as if the the economy had not grown at all. Openings are up considerably because employers won't raise wages and have learned just to keep an elevated level of openings. Otherwise you would see more hires. There is no skills shortage. Real wages (nominal minus inflation) are barely up 1%, the gains skewed to upper incomes, aided by oil price induced low inflation still rippling through economy, and DNWR which coasts well above 0% for most workers.

https://www.bls.gov/web/jolts/jlt_labstatgraphs.pdf
http://cepr.net/blogs/cepr-blog/we-need-more-quitters

We are five years away from full employment, at least.
I can't believe people "rec'd" this. Sorry wages are rising and have been rising the last 2 years at a real pace the fastest in almost 20 years. Get a clue if you don't understand what is happening.

A wonderful quote that sparked my memories of amazing bird behaviors. Loved the word chandelles which I looked up after the solve. Started with ESTRAGON, BANJOIST, UGLINESS, APPREHEND, and DAN RATHER. Had to research RAJASTHAN and LOVE CHILD which I could not recall. Did finally remember about HEMINGWAY; One year I had been given a calendar about "literary" cats. Mark Twain was also a cat lover, if I remember correctly. Welcome back Deb and thanks to Caitlin.
